importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's update, indicating the most current information on the political developments surrounding Curtis Sliwa’s mayoral campaign.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period during which key political developments, including Catsimatidis’s public call for Sliwa to withdraw and Sliwa’s rebuttal, occurred.

keyTakeAways: Curtis Sliwa, a Republican candidate for New York City mayor, is under pressure to withdraw from the race due to pressure from his boss, John Catsimatidis, and other Republican figures who support Governor Andrew Cuomo as an independent alternative to Democratic nominee Zohran Mamdani.
John Catsimatidis, a Republican supermarket magnate and longtime New Yorker, publicly urged Sliwa to drop out, citing loyalty and the need for Sliwa to love New York more than anything else.

Andrew Cuomo, running as an independent, has been actively pushing to consolidate Republican opposition to Zohran Mamdani, arguing Sliwa is not a viable alternative and that supporting him may effectively mean supporting Mamdani.

Sliwa has dismissed the pressure, asserting that he represents blue-collar working-class voters and rejecting the notion that billionaire donors or political figures like Trump or Bill Ackman can determine election outcomes.
President Donald Trump has dismissed Sliwa as a weak candidate, mocking his affinity for cats and animal rescues, which has further intensified the political debate around Sliwa’s viability.
Sliwa, best known for founding the Guardian Angels, has never held political office and is polling third in the mayoral race behind Mamdani and Cuomo.

Mamdani has responded to claims of coordination with Sliwa by laughing them off, emphasizing that both candidates agree on the need for New Yorkers to make their own choice, not for elite donors to dictate the outcome.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Curtis Sliwa, a Republican candidate for New York City mayor, is facing mounting pressure to drop out of the race from his boss John Catsimatidis and other Republicans who support Governor Andrew Cuomo as an independent alternative to Democratic nominee Zohran Mamdani. Catsimatidis, who owns WABC-AM, publicly urged Sliwa to withdraw, stating he should love New York more than anything. Cuomo has criticized Sliwa as unviable and argued that supporting him is equivalent to supporting Mamdani. In response, Sliwa has defended his candidacy, asserting that he represents working-class voters and rejecting the influence of billionaire donors. Trump has dismissed Sliwa as unimpressive, mocking his affinity for cats and animal rescues. Despite criticism, Sliwa remains in the race, with Mamdani dismissing claims of coordination between the two candidates and emphasizing that New Yorkers should make their own choice.
title: Curtis Sliwa’s boss becomes the latest Republican trying to push him out of NYC mayoral race
